definition: to throw stones at sb who fell down a well (idiom); to hit a person who is down
colloquial reading for 落[luo4] in certain compounds
to fall or drop/(of the sun) to set/(of a tide) to go out/to lower/to decline or sink/to lag or fall behind/to fall onto/to rest with/to get or receive/to write down/whereabouts/settlement
to leave out/to be missing/to leave behind or forget to bring/to lag or fall behind
Jing, one of the 28 constellations of Chinese astronomy/surname Jing
a well/CL:口[kou3]/neat/orderly
down/downwards/below/lower/later/next (week etc)/second (of two parts)/to decline/to go down/to arrive at (a decision, conclusion etc)/measure word to show the frequency of an action
dry measure for grain equal to ten dou 斗/ten pecks/one hundred liters
rock/stone/stone inscription/one of the eight categories of ancient musical instruments 八音[ba1 yin1]
surname Shi

sentences.english: Are Chinese reporters really so eager to flog their British peers?
sentences.chinese: 中國傳媒真的這麼渴望對他們的英國同行落井下石嗎？

sentences.english: On the right, that gangsters and anti-social elements are taking advantage of tragedy.
sentences.chinese: 右翼則認爲，搶匪和反社會分子乘此機會落井下石。

sentences.english: Las Vegas handicapped the underdogs by a large margin.
sentences.chinese: 拉斯維加斯對失敗者落井下石。

sentences.english: To demand money from a person who has just lost his job is hitting a man who is down.
sentences.chinese: 向一個剛剛失業的人討債等於落井下石。

definition: lit. to destroy the bridge after crossing the river (idiom)/fig. to abandon one's benefactor upon achieving one's goal
to loot a burning house/to profit from sb's misfortune (idiom)
to forget favors and violate justice (idiom); ingratitude to a friend/to kick a benefactor in the teeth
to bite the hand that feeds one (idiom)
to make a false countercharge
harboring unfathomable motives (idiom)
lit. to kill the donkey when the grinding is done (idiom)/to get rid of sb once he has ceased to be useful
lit. to strike with a muckrake (idiom), cf Pigsy 豬八戒|猪八戒 in Journey to the West 西遊記|西游记; fig. to counterattack/to make bogus accusations (against one's victim)
to sow dissension (idiom); to drive a wedge between
to entrap/to set up/to frame (up)/to make false charges against
breaking faith and abandoning right (idiom); to betray/treachery/perfidy
frigid irony and scorching satire (idiom); to mock and ridicule
to watch with folded arms (idiom); to look on without lifting a finger
two-faced, three knives (idiom); double-cross/double dealing and back stabbing
to speak out for justice (idiom); to take a stand on a matter of principle
lit. see the wind and set the helm (idiom); fig. to act pragmatically/to be flexible and take advantage of the situation
